displayed_text: Family Member: No. Patient: Yeah. I remember him saying that. Doctor: Yeah. I wouldn’t say that. There’s no number that, huh, I can tell you there’s no number that I get excited about. Family Member 1: He said if the number went up too many times, he would check the scans because he doesn’t go by the number. The number just shows that that medicine wasn’t necessary. Patient: I wonder how long I’ve had this damn cancer. Doctor: And you get your blood work Quest LabCorp here? Patient: B___. Family Member: B___. Doctor: And you got it the same day you saw me or you got, you went over there earlier today or-? Family Member: He got it done here today. They made an appointment here today. Doctor: Okay. Huh, but normally you go to B___? Family Member: Yes.

Patient: I put high marks because I understand because we trust… Doctor: Well I’m glad you understand because otherwise – otherwise you’re not gonna do what’s good for you. Patient: You’re right and I listen. You listen to me and I… Doctor: You sure do listen. Yeah. Patient: That’s what I like about everything. Doctor: So I’m going to give you three scripts. Okay. One for the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The new one and then the OxyContin and then uh your Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now what’s going on with your Zometa and everything? That’s XGEVA is B___ doing that?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. You do not need a special diet; you do not need special things. What is important is you don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you stay physically active. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all that’s important because I mean what is bad is if you get fat, fat is a pro-inflammatory environment and people who do get fat die quicker from cancer. All cancers. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, so, all these diets and things like that, all these special things people offer often at high prices, you know it’s great if you need that discipline, but the reality is don’t gain weight. Stay in shape; you’ll do better. Patient: So like worrying about my sugar intake and - Doctor: Don’t – in or out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: It’s amazing. I was very impressed. Patient: Well she reminded me of the bakery and I don’t remember the bakery. Family Member: Oh yeah we went to xxx]. Doctor: They’re known for their that specific bakery. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: You know it’s funny but at the check-in at the airline this guy wrote down the name of the bakery because I had no idea that it’s known for its desserts and bakery so I had to go there. chuckles]] Family Member: Oh yeah. Patient: So anyway back to the problem. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Your husband did what he does. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And so this is gonna show us if if it worked?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, Yeah. Because we can have S____ call you or somebody in our social work team. Do you want to do that? So we get proactive on this? Patient: I’m not ready for that. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. Patient: Um, but I know that that help is there. Doctor: So yeah, of course. Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay. So I think, you know, depending on so you'll finish reading the consent, if it's of interest call M___ back and say, okay, their next step would be to bring you in and actually formally review everything and get blood work on that day- Patient: Mhm.

Patient: So they have the – I don’t know what they call it. It’s the trial on the nights where they Doctor: Yeah. Patient: they radiate and see if they’re hitting the targets that they want to. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: But I think that’s more like an x-ray or a CT scan or whatever. Doctor: Okay, I’ll find out from him. Patient: So and - Doctor: Okay. We’ll get a plan. Patient: So it was described to be by the nurses. It’s the last time they tweak the aim if they’re not exactly satisfied with the - Doctor: Mm hmm, it might be IMRT, you know sort of image modulated radiation therapy. Patient: Don’t know that. Doctor: Okay, so I can check with him. I know what M___s going to do is try to have you sign a form so we could see if you could be eligible for this other study. Um, it is a pill drug.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If you decided to participate in a different clinical trial, then, of course, you could receive that therapy here as long as K___ approved of you to enroll in that trial, which they probably will, because their general policy is if you’re participating in a trial at an institution that’s not available through K___, then they support that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you could definitely still be our patient, and we would love it if you were. Uh, we’ve gotten to know you for the past several months, and I think your experience with us has also been relatively good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so, you know, that could be a win-win, but we have to make sure that it’s something that makes sense for you. We’re not going to put you on a trial just for the sake of keeping you at H___. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it just might be that we have something that really does look interesting or promising that we can offer you. I don’t want to go into those details today because I don’t know when that time will come or if it will come. But if that time comes, when we’re deciding between a standard therapy, like the two that I mentioned, or a different experimental therapy, I can give you the consent form, and you can think about it, and if you decide to participate that would be through us. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Because I know the discussion we had initially, uh, was the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That was one of the options. And I used the word, chemo bad. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s bad in terms, you know, the side effects are worse than everything you’ve had so far.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And so that would be something that you know, based on sort of, if we really think T12 is real or T3 is real, that could be something that we would send you off to the radiation doctors to have them talk about that trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then we get the PET scan and it actually says, you know, you've got 123 plus 456, you know, that we think most of this is real, we can step back and watch a little bit longer until either declares itself a little bit more. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or just say hey, it's there. And then we have a couple studies where the current standard for the guy who shows up with multiple spots is to go on hormones for life. Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Oh, I got you. Doctor: Radium, there’s liquid radiation, there’s Xofigo, which is the trade name, and, you know, we don’t give it but the radiation oncology doctors give it because it is a form of radiation. So, they’ll go over everything but what I would do is we would start the prior authorization process with our insurance but you then would talk to the radiation oncology doctor for a formal consultation and then they go over the pros and cons of what’s gonna happen and so on and so on. Patient: You know about it I’m sure about this. You know about the radiation that I had Doctor: Uh huh. Yep Patient: and is it similar to that or is the… Doctor: Different. Patient: Side effects? Doctor: You could have had the radiation. This is intravenous infusion. You know what this is, is the stuff that Marie Curie discovered all those years ago in the late eighteen hundreds. That’s what she discovered to try to treat cancer and now we actually use to treat cancer. Patient: Oh, wow! Doctor: Yeah. It’s just in smaller doses. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, I think the fact you’ve had radiation before is not, you know, an issue.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: So, it’s in there. I’m supposed to go over it with ya. You know, then you have people like T_, myself, C_ as resources, to just say, “Hey, you know, my nails - It could be that every time I’m getting chemo, things stop growing.” And then once the chemo is out of your body, it starts growing, so you’re gonna get ridges. Family Member: Ohhh. Doctor: So, you can sorta like. Doctor: Exactly. So, you’ll sorta know those sorts of things. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah, the chemo class will sorta tell you a little bit about what’s more, like normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, you know, you’re gonna likely - you know seventy-five percent of people lose their hair on this. Family Member: So, is that - Doctor: And that tends to grow back Family Member: That class, is that here? Or is that a web cast?

Family Member: I have that, yeah. Doctor: Do it yourself, but otherwise, if you just tell the operator then at eight hundred to page what - Patient: Give me your Christmas present. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Okay (chuckles) Patient: No, there you go. Doctor: Oh, thank you. Patient: You’re welcome. Doctor: That is very sweet. Family Member: Yeah, it is. Doctor: Thank you, that’s special, though; thank you. Okay, so the other big thing is that this chemo will cause hair loss. You probably will notice; most people notice it after about a couple of courses. But you know it’s possible Patient: What’s the

Family Member: So, um, we’ve had a little bit of a (pause) Doctor: So, so, well, here, here’s - I have lack of flexibility. So, again, I can only see you on Tuesdays. Family Member: Got it. Doctor: Okay? So, again, unless we give you the chemo on the same day, but it’s going to be Wednesday or Thursday. Um. And, again, most people are not under the bed. Most, unless you, you are puking your guts out which is pretty rare. Most people are just, sort of, feel like that they’ve, um - “I—I- I gotta go take a nap.” Family Member: Yeah, that’s what T_ said. Doctor: So, I- I--I am just gonna go take a nap. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s not bad. There’s nothing wrong with ya. You know, if you’re achy- Patient: Just tired. Doctor: Just ‘cuz, you know, you’re just take a couple of Advil, and you just say, “I, I gotta go take a nap.” Most people don’t notice much. Uh, just like, “Okay, they told me I’d feel it this weekend.” Uh. Family Member: Okay! Doctor: Most people really just lose the end of their day. You know, they’re at work, work, work, and they just sorta say, “Oh.” And they’re toast. Patient: And when the end of the day is all over, you nap.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: ‘Cuz – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Don’t – Patient: And I can just – Doctor: Don’t aggravate! Patient: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference. Doctor: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window – Patient: Right. Doctor: Where we gotta make a decision – Patient: So okay, doc. So, let me --

Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right? Doctor: Correct Patient: Because you advised no magnesium? Doctor: Well, no. A normal level of magnesium is good. Patient: A normal level Family Member: Like in a multivitamin magnesium? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play. Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation.
